news.title: Two dangerous criminals escape from Zimbabwean prison
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

A DARING escape was reported Saturday afternoon at St Thomas prison facility in Marondera, where two prisoners managed to break free from custody.

According to sources, the two inmates from the D Class classified as dangerous, scaled the perimetre fence and made good their escape in broad daylight around noon, just after a visit by friends and relatives raising fears of an inside job.

Sources told NewZimbabwe.com. that one of the unidentified escapees was serving time for armed robbery while the other for rape.

A thorough investigation is reportedly underway to determine circumstances surrounding the escape and identify potential lapses in security protocols. Reports say the wardens on duty were not vigilant, particularly considering that they were watching over D Class inmates.

ZPCS national spokesperson, Assistant Commissioner Meya Khanyezi

Zimbabwe Prisons and Correctional Services (ZPCS) has reportedly launched a manhunt for the escapees although authorities have remained tight-lipped over the shocking daylight jail break.

Efforts to get comment from Zimbabwe Prisons and Correctional Services (ZPCS) spokesperson, Assistant Commissioner Meya Khanyezi were fruitless by the time of publishing.

The incident has sparked panic among Marondera residents, who were sending alerts on social media in the absence of official warning and appeal for vigilance from ZPCS itself.

news.title: Trio in court for US$22,000 worth of dagga
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

THREE drug peddlers have been convicted by the Masvingo Magistrates Court for unlawful possession of 175 kilogrammes of dagga, with an estimated street value of US$22,000.

The offenders, Ali Allan Mamudu (55), Khumbo Njima (45) and Lombikan Mwanandi (36) were busted in an anti-drug operation by the police on March 9, 2025.They were sentenced to 12 years imprisonment, of which three years were suspended for five years. They will each serve an effective nine years behind bars.Court heard that investigators got information that offenders were involved in dagga smuggling and using a bus enroute to Malawi.Detectives located the bus at Bulawayo turnoff in Masvingo after it had developed a mechanical fault. Upon arrival, police officers observed the trio transferring transparent plastic parcels containing dagga to a commuter omnibus.Upon noticing cops, two of the offenders fled the scene in a Volkswagen Polo, abandoning a significant portion of the dagga.The third offender was apprehended and after a search of the commuter omnibus, 17 plastic-wrapped parcels of dagga were recovered.The two fugitive suspects were later apprehended on March 11 this year in Harare and the getaway car was seized.In a statement following sentencing, the National Prosecuting Authority of Zimbabwe (NPAZ) noted that drug trafficking is destroying lives and communities across Zimbabwe.

news.title: FC Platinum record humiliating 5-2 defeat to Scottland
news.content:
By Sports Reporter

FC Platinums 23-match unbeaten run ended Saturday with a 5-2 defeat to Scottland FC at Mandava Stadium in Zvishavane, Midlands province.

The result saw Scottland FC maintaining pressure on log leaders Simba Bhora, who are now on 47 points after beating Chicken Inn 1-0.With 46 points, Scottland FC are second on the table, and thave now gone for five games without dropping a point.Saturdays result had a huge impact not for FC Platinum coach Norman Mapeza as an individual, who revealed that this was his highest score margin defeat since he started coaching.Its my first time in my coaching career to lose by five goals, its my first time.I think they managed to make use of their chances, which we gave them. Were not giving up,we still have to keep fighting and see how this happens, said MapezaDespite the defeat, FC Platinum is still on fourth position with 40 points and a game in hand.Saturdays match gave the fans value for their money as both side staged classic displays.However, the visiting death depth was the x-factor, which saw them walking away with three points.Scottland had the luxury of starting star players Khama Billiat and new high profile signing Knowledge Musona on the bench, only to introduce them in the dying minutes of the game while they were already leading 4-2.Striker Tymon Machope was the hero as he managed to score a brace before he was substituted in the 63rd minute.I think the quality showed today, and Ive always said that football is played by quality.But at the same time, if you have quality that doesnt run, then you risk not winning matches.Im happy that today we saw the running from the quality that we have, and that then got us the results, said Scottland FC coach Tonderai Ndiraya.Meanwhile, fellow title contenders TelOne FC were handed a 1-0 defeat at home by Manica Diamonds, who ended their seven match winless run at Ascot Stadium in Gweru.Elsewhere, at Nyamhunga Stadium in Kariba, Greenfuel recorded a 1-0 win against ZPC Kariba while Dynamos shockingly defeated MWOS 1-0 at Rufaro Stadium to mark their third defeat of the season.

news.title: Bokola Festival 2025 to spotlight climate change, inequality and war
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

SEVERAL filmmakers are expected to flock to Studio Moto on August 23 for this years edition of the Bokola Festival.

The arts fiesta, a Magamba Network initiative, has been running since 2020 and will this year run under the theme: Dream. Now!

The festival will shine a spotlight on climate change, inequality, and war, with filmmakers challenged to curate projects aligned with this theme.

Bokola Festival co-director Sikhanyisiwe Sebata is looking forward to a refreshing edition, extending an invitation to filmmakers.

Were so excited to bring Bokola 2025 to Studio Moto; a vibrant, immersive space where creativity and community meet.

We invite everyone to experience powerful films, meaningful conversations, and a fresh energy that reflects the spirit of Bokola, said Sebata

The event will showcase compelling documentary screenings across three curated strands: Stories From The Emergency, Dreamers, and Frontlines of Change.

Bokola Festival Co-Director Dexter Fundire said this years edition has been rebranded to introduce an exciting new element.

This year, Bokola has been rebranded. Were focusing on youthe people. Your films, your dreams, your experiences, Fundire said.

Organisers have opened submissions for filmmakers to submit their work for consideration.

news.title: ZRP embraces technology in combating crime as 27 police officers graduate with drone pilot certificates
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

THE Zimbabwe Republic Police (ZRP) is entrenching the use of technology in combating crime in the wake of sophisticated criminal syndicates.

This follows the graduation with drone pilot certificates of a cohort of 27 police officer in Harare this Wednesday after successfully undergoing rigorous training.National police spokesperson, Commissioner Paul Nyathi said the event underscored ZRPs commitment to modernising policing and keeping abreast with international best standards and protocols.As the ZRP continues to embrace technology in policing, 27 police officers graduated with drone pilot certificates at ZRP Sports Club this afternoon, Nyathi said in a statement Wednesday.The CommissionerGeneral of Polices thrust of modernising the ZRP through the Electronic Traffic Management System and use of technology in crime management is certainly taking effect, he added.Drones are a game-changer in combating crime as they can be deployed in surveillance and monitoring large crowds, areas, or events, helping to prevent and respond to crimes.They can also track suspects, monitor traffic, and survey crime scenes while drones with facial recognition technology can help identify known troublemakers or wanted individuals in crowds.In search and rescue operations, drones equipped with thermal sensors and high-zoom cameras can quickly locate missing persons or suspects in vast areas while in crime scene Investigation they can help investigators analyse evidence and piece together what happened.In border control, Zimbabwe has already started using drones to patrol its borders, helping to curb cross-border crimes like smuggling and human trafficking.Also, these special tools, equipped with specialised sensors, can detect explosives or hazardous materials from a safe distance, protecting police officers and the public.

news.title: Liverpool loans Warriors prospect Isaac Mabaya to Wigan
news.content:
By Sports Reporter

WARRIORS prospect Isaac Mabaya has been loaned to EFL League One side Wigan Athletics by Liverpool.

Mabayas move was confirmed by Wigan on Friday in a loan deal that will see him at the club until June 2026.

Aged 20, the young defender is one of Liverpools academy products contracted out this season to seek game time elsewhere.

I know how big the club is, and I cant wait to play in front of the fans.

I have heard about how important the supporters are to the team and how good the fanbase is, and I cant wait to play in front of them, commented Mabaya on his new move.

Mabaya has represented England in various youth levels, and he marked his debut for Liverpool senior side last year under Jurgen Klopp.

The youthful right back played two games under Arne Slott this year, that is a UEFA Champions League clash against PSV Eindoven and Emirates FA Cup clash against Plymouth Argyle.

Commening on Mabayas arrival, Wigan Athletic coach Ryan Lowe said,Ive known of Isaac for many years  hes had a few injuries, but feels like hes back to where he belongs.

I nearly signed him when I was at Preston North End, knowing his pedigree and what hes about hes a powerful right wing-back, who will definitely give us something down the right-hand side.

news.title: Municipal worker dies in refuse truck accident
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

A CHITUNGWIZA municipal worker, Simon Maketo, died Thursday after sustaining injuries in a tragic workplace accident that occurred while he was on duty in Manyame Park.

Maketo reportedly hit his head against a precast wall and lost balance after the truck attempted to navigate around a stationary commuter omnibus obstructing its path.In a statement Friday, Municipality of Chitungwiza said Maketo was rushed to St Marys Clinic and later transferred to Chitungwiza Central Hospital, where he was pronounced dead on arrival.Preliminary reports indicate that during refuse collection, the refuse truck encountered a stationary commuter omnibus obstructing it. Mr. Maketo was positioned on the right side of the truck.As the driver attempted to maneuver around the obstruction, Mr. Maketo reportedly panicked, hitting his head against a precast wall before being struck again by the truck. He then lost balance and fell to the ground.He was immediately rushed to St Marys Clinic and later transferred to Chitungwiza Central Hospital by our municipal ambulance.Unfortunately, he was pronounced dead on arrival, the statement reads.

news.title: Seven years on, no justice for victims of Zimbabwe’s August 2018 army shootings
news.content:
By Thandiwe Garusa

SEVEN years after the brutal army shootings of August 1, 2018, human rights activists are still demanding justice for the victims.

In 2018, six unarmed civilians were shot dead in Harare after the army was deployed to stop demonstrations by opposition supporters, who were protesting in the streets, demanding the release of the Presidential election results.

There was a delay in releasing Presidential poll results by the Zimbabwe Electoral Commission (ZEC). raising suspicion of manipulation of results.

The six who were killed are Silvia Maphosa, Ishmael Kumire, Brian Zhuwawo, Gavin Dean Charles, Jealous Chikandira and Challenge Tauro.

Following the killings, a Commission of Inquiry chaired by former South African President Kgalema Motlanthe was appointed by President Emmerson Mnangagwa to probe the post-July 2018 election and violence recommended that the government should compensate all the victims of the shootings and prosecute all perpetrators.

In a statement Friday, human rights lobbyists, Amnesty International Zimbabwe, reiterated calls for the government to implement the Motlanthe Commission recommendations.

Today, 1 August 2025, marks seven years since the shooting of civilians by soldiers during protests in the aftermath of the 2018 Zimbabwe general elections.

We demand justice for the victims, their families and call upon the government to implement recommendations of the Motlanthe Commission, the statement reads.

To date, no known victims or families have been compensated and there has been no prosecution of perpetrators.

The government has been for long accused of lacking the will to implement recommendations proffered by the inquiry panel.
